moves.1. d4 d5 2. Nc3 Nf6: The unfamiliar Queen's Pawn Chigorin variation plays role here. It si a more common version and the winning percentages (thanks to a website called chessebook.com) are: 1-0=12%  1/2=52%  0-1=36%. This is an opening advantage for black.
moves.3. f3 Nc6 4. e3 Bf5: Not the best move for a center challenge.
moves.5. e4: I was worried about this move until I saw that I had the advantage.
moves.5... dxe4 6. g4: Why did white have to do this flimsy pawn move? Sure, your Bishop has a totally open line, but do you have space for early pawn pushes?
moves.6... Bg6: If I still want to protect the e-pawn, I had to do this move.
moves.7. Be3: White puts more pressure on his d-pawn, not realizing what was going to happen. Suppose he played 7.Bg2, then he would have prevented me from doing the next three moves.
moves.7... Qd6: I was expecting white to do 8.Bb5, but I was unprepared for white's next move.
moves.8. Nxe4: Suddenly, this thought traveled in my head, "Big miscalculation."
moves.8... Bxe4 9. fxe4 Nxe4: White's entire opening process was destroyed! Now, white must develope his back rank pieces in order to keep this game going.
moves.10. Nf3: In desperation to recover his d-pawn's defence and to fling it down the isle, he played this move?!
moves.10... e5: e5!? was an attempt to trick white.
moves.11. Bb5: A pathetic bishop move. Better is 11.Bd3!? or 11.Bg2.
moves.11... Qb4+ 12. Bd2 Qxb5: The bishop is gone. White cannot castle. To make matters worse, White's king side is being pried open!
moves.13. b3 Bb4 14. a4 Qa5: White's pawns put me in a position to sucessfully challenge d2 or d4.
moves.15. O-O: 15.O-O is a complete disaster to the king side.
moves.15... exd4 16. Qe1 O-O-O 17. c3: This blazing blunder cost White the game.
moves.17... Nxc3: Here we go again. White stops trading with me after I play this move. Maybe White's Queen is fixed on the the open e-file.
moves.18. g5 g6 19. h4 Ne2+: I desperately rushed to grab the bishop with this crazy blunder. I quickly lose the d2 trade.
moves.20. Qxe2 Rhe8: I had to play this to recover the trade.
moves.21. Qc4 Bxd2: Because of White's dubious move, I eliminated White's bishop.
moves.22. Qxf7 Be3+: White can hardly play any move that can turn the tables around.
moves.23. Kg2 Qd2+ 24. Kg3 Re7: White's plan to get my pawns to promote his pawns failed because of the use of one piece. His Queen has to retreat.
moves.25. Qc4 Bf4+ 26. Kg4: White's King is on the road of death. He is trapped by several pieces; some are his own!
moves.26... Ne5+ 27. Kh3 Nxc4 28. Nxd2: Oh well, we traded Queens. Something back-fired because now, White has three possile winning threats!
moves.28... Re3+: I liked this move; the only problem is, how can I protect my pieces (the bishop and the knight) from winning takes?!
moves.29. Kg4 Rf8 30. Rfg1: Problem solved. White seemed to have ignored 30.bxc4. This knight becomes the powerhouse!
moves.34... Ne4 35. h5 Rg3+ 36. Kh4 Rf4#: Moral: too much pawn structure can lead to many flaws.
